results.title: To do or not to do.....
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Jock Noble
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Jock Noble, CEO of Diversity@work Australia, talks about the impact having Polio had on his childhood and how that has subsequently shaped his career in helping companies to strengthen through diversity in their workforce.

results.title: Why?
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Tehree Gordon
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Tehree says she is an ordinary Australian, though she was a recipient of the Senior Australian of the Year Award in 2004. In this story, Tehree talks about her passion for wildlife from an early age leading to her founding Jirrahlinga Koala and Wildlife Sanctuary with her partner Hamish. The sanctuary has provided work opportunities and enrichment to people living with disabilities and the elderly.

results.title: Doors Will Open
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Rajani Shrestha
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Rajani Shrestha moved to Melbourne from Nepal in 1992 with her husband and son. Rajani recounts the struggle she faced to find meaningful work in a new country. She tells of her journey which eventually led to her working at AMES Australia.

results.title: My Banquet...
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Chey Scovell
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Chey Scovell recounts his childhood growing up as an Australian born in Malaysia and the last four years of schooling spent in Papua New Guinea. He tells of the culture shock he experienced when returning back to Australia.

results.title: An Airman at sea
results.brief_description: As Keith flew from Townsville to Milne Bay in Papua New Guinea, he wondered if he would ever see the shores of Australia again. Suffering from dengue fever, Keith battled illness the whole time. He made it back when the war ended and would go on to serve in the RAFF for 20 years.

results.title: A Rookie airman's story
results.brief_description: Cliff’s father was a fisherman, so he knew about boats. After joining the airforce in 1942 he would spend the majority of his service running missions on boats. Lucky he didn’t tell them he couldn’t swim.

results.title: On borrowed time
results.brief_description: Keith was a member of a Catalina crew in the airforce and the loss of their captain on a mission affected the whole crew. After almost drowning in the plane as she went down in the ocean crash, Keith was not able to fly again.
results.description: Keith was a member of a Catalina crew in the airforce and the loss of their captain on a mission affected the whole crew. After almost drowning in the plane as she went down in the ocean crash, Keith was not able to fly again.

results.title: In my blood
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Jack Bell and ACMI
results.brief_description: Serving in Libya , Jack was captured and became a POW. Almost dying from injures , he would spend over 3 months in prisoner camps in Europe. Today he still remember his mates who didn’t make it and the doctor who who saved his life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Jack Bell and ACMI

group_siblings.title: Why did we fight?: the experience of a Vietnamese Veteran

results.title: Will you hold my hand?
results.brief_description: Pegg Utting was one of the first women to join the newly formed WAAAF in 1941. Her son would later join up to serve in Vietnam aged 17. Like so many others he struggled to fit in when he returned. After many years, he was finally invited to March with the RSL and it was Peg’s loving support that got him through this.
results.description: Pegg Utting was one of the first women to join the newly formed WAAAF in 1941. Her son would later join up to serve in Vietnam aged 17. Like so many others he struggled to fit in when he returned. After many years, he was finally invited to March with the RSL and it was Peg’s loving support that got him through this.

results.title: Why did we fight?: the experience of a Vietnamese Veteran
results.brief_description: Hung and his family were originally from North Vietnam but after fleeing as a child to the South, he would follow in this father’s footsteps and join the army to fight for freedom. After being captured and spending years in re-education camps, his family finally decided to flee to Australia to start a new life.
